deliberation: I looked for explicit comparisons (similes), metaphors, and conventional anthropomorphic or metonymic expressions. The verse contains a clear simile involving fire, and two separate metonymic/anthropomorphic expressions relating to God's 'name' and 'face/presence.'

instances.english_text: As when fire kindles brushwood, and fire makes water boil
vehicle: Fire that suddenly kindles brushwood and makes water boil
ground: Sudden, violent, uncontrollable, and transformative impact
Shared experiential effect on the surroundings
posture: The speaker’s urgent wish for a theophany as fierce as raging fire
instances.explanation: God’s hoped-for intervention is explicitly compared to the way a blazing fire rapidly ignites dry brush and makes water boil—an image of sudden, overwhelming power, intensified to convey a shocking theophany.

instances.english_text: to make Your name known to Your adversaries
target: God’s reputation and manifested character among enemies
ground: A personal name stands for the whole person’s identity and reputation
posture: The speaker wants God’s true reputation to be displayed before hostile nations
instances.explanation: ‘Name’ stands metonymically for God’s revealed identity, character, and reputation; the request is not for mere knowledge of a label but for recognition of who God truly is.

instances.english_text: so that nations will tremble at Your Presence
ground: The face represents someone’s presence, attention, and favor or anger
posture: The nations’ fear is tied to encountering God’s manifest presence, not merely to abstract knowledge
instances.explanation: ‘Your face/presence’ is a standard metonymy for God’s active nearness—His favor or terrifying self-disclosure before which nations ‘tremble.’

deliberation: I examined the description of God’s action (‘You came down’) and the response of the mountains. These are classic theophanic images. I identified anthropomorphic spatial language for God and a vivid, hyperbolic portrayal of mountains reacting to God’s presence.

instances.english_text: You came down
target: God’s intervention from transcendence into history
vehicle: A person physically descending from a higher place
ground: Crossing a boundary from ‘above’ to ‘below’, entering another’s sphere
posture: The speaker conceptualizes God’s intervention as spatial descent to stress nearness and involvement
instances.explanation: God, who is not spatially located like a human, is depicted metaphorically as ‘coming down’ from heaven to earth, an anthropomorphic way of expressing His active intervention.

instances.english_text: Before You the mountains quaked/melted
target: The created order’s response to God’s manifest presence
ground: Overwhelming, destabilizing effect of God’s presence portrayed as if solid mountains lose their stability
Response of weaker reality before overwhelming power
posture: The speaker dramatizes God’s past deeds by describing even mountains as if they collapse or melt
instances.explanation: The mountains are described in hyperbolic, quasi-personified terms as ‘flowing’ or ‘melting’ before God, conveying the idea that even the most stable parts of creation cannot stand unchanged in His presence.

deliberation: I checked whether ‘hearing’ and ‘seeing’ here are simply literal sensory verbs or form a rhetorical figure. The paired negations (hearing/attending vs seeing) from ‘of old’ function as a meristic hyperbole, stressing the unprecedented nature of God’s acts.

instances.hebrew_text: וּמֵעוֹלָם לֹא־שָׁמְעוּ לֹא הֶאֱזִינוּ עַיִן לֹא־רָאָתָה אֱלֹהִים זוּלָתְךָ
instances.english_text: Such things had never been heard or noted. No eye has seen [them], O God, but You
target: Any precedent for a God acting as YHWH does
vehicle: Total lack of sensory report: no hearing, no attentive listening, no seeing ‘from of old’
ground: Using the main senses (hearing and seeing) in paired negation to convey ‘no one has ever experienced or known such a thing’
posture: The speaker exalts God by claiming His acts are beyond all known experience
instances.explanation: The pairing of ‘hearing/attending’ and ‘seeing’ in sweeping negation is a meristic hyperbole: by invoking all main avenues of perception, the text stresses that nothing comparable has ever been known.

deliberation: I evaluated the verbs for literalness and the noun ‘ways’ for possible metaphor. The primary figurative element is the common metaphor of ‘ways’ as patterns of conduct or dealings, applied here to God’s dealings.

instances.english_text: And remember You in Your ways
target: God’s characteristic dealings, commandments, and modes of action
ground: A path along which one walks corresponds to a course of action one follows
Stable, recognizable pattern that can be followed or recalled
posture: The speaker describes God’s dealings as ‘paths’ within which the faithful remember Him
instances.explanation: ‘Your ways’ uses the conventional biblical metaphor CONDUCT/DEALINGS AS A WAY/PATH: God’s characteristic actions toward His people are conceptualized as tracks on which they can ‘walk’ and within which they ‘remember’ Him.

deliberation: This verse is densely figurative. I identified four distinct כְּ-/כַ-comparisons: (1) the community as an unclean thing, (2) their righteous acts as a filthy rag, (3) themselves as withering leaves, and (4) their iniquities as a wind that carries them off. Each uses a different vehicle and grounds a different aspect of their spiritual condition.

instances.english_text: We have all become like an impure thing
target: The moral/ritual condition of the people
vehicle: An ‘unclean thing’ (טָמֵא), ritually defiled object or person
ground: Both are unsuitable for contact with the holy and must be avoided/cleansed
posture: The speaker confesses corporate defilement in extreme terms
instances.explanation: The people’s condition is likened to a single ‘unclean thing,’ emphasizing their unfitness to approach God; the simile is hyperbolic to accent the depth of defilement.

instances.english_text: And all our virtues [righteous deeds] like a filthy rag
ground: What appears outwardly serviceable is in fact disgusting and defiling
posture: The speaker drastically devalues their ‘righteous’ acts
instances.explanation: By comparing their ‘righteousnesses’ to a filthy cloth, the text uses shocking imagery to stress that even their best deeds are tainted and unpresentable before God.

instances.english_text: We are all withering like leaves
target: The people’s frailty and decline under judgment
vehicle: A leaf that withers and dries up
ground: Both are transient, fragile, easily shriveled and carried away
posture: The speaker highlights human frailty under divine displeasure
instances.explanation: The community is likened to withering leaves, stressing transience and powerlessness in the face of judgment.

instances.english_text: And our iniquities, like a wind, carry us off
target: The destructive, destabilizing effect of the people’s sins upon themselves
vehicle: A strong wind that drives things away
Forces of nature that sweep away light objects
ground: Both sins and wind exert impersonal, overpowering force that drives people from stability and safety
posture: The speaker portrays sin as an active, external force that overwhelms them
instances.explanation: Their iniquities are depicted as if they were a gusting wind that ‘carries’ them away, personifying sin as an active agent and emphasizing how their own wrongdoing uproots them.

deliberation: I examined whether the language of calling on God, hiding God’s face, and being melted in the hand of iniquities is literal. All three are conventional figurative expressions: grasping God as a metaphor for seeking Him, hiding God’s face as idiomatic for withdrawing favor, and being melted in the ‘hand’ of iniquities as a composite metaphor/personification.

instances.english_text: rouses themselves to cling to You / to take hold of You
target: Earnest turning to God in prayer and dependence
vehicle: Physically seizing and holding onto someone
ground: Both imply firm, intentional, urgent attachment that will not let go
posture: The speaker laments the lack of determined, clinging pursuit of God
instances.explanation: No one literally takes hold of God’s body; physical grasping is a metaphorical and idiomatic way to describe whole-hearted, active reliance on Him.

instances.english_text: For You have hidden Your face from us
target: God’s withdrawal of favor and saving presence
vehicle: A person turning away or covering their face so as not to be seen
ground: Hidden or averted face signals distance, displeasure, and lack of communication
posture: The speaker interprets their distress as relational estrangement from God
instances.explanation: God is portrayed anthropomorphically as hiding His ‘face’; the face stands metonymically for His favorable presence, so hiding it idiomatically expresses His withdrawal and displeasure.

instances.english_text: And [You] have made us melt in the hand of our iniquities
target: The community’s helpless condition under the consequences/power of its sins
vehicle: Melting in someone’s hand, like wax or snow under pressure and heat
Soft material dissolving in another’s grasp
ground: Both depict loss of firmness and autonomy under a dominating force (‘hand’ as power)
Complete vulnerability and dissolution under control
posture: The speaker dramatizes their misery as being undone and dominated by their own sins, under God’s decree
instances.explanation: Their iniquities are given a ‘hand’ (metonymy for power) and treated as a kind of captor; the people are ‘melted’ in that hand, a vivid metaphor and personification of sin’s crushing, disintegrating grip, heightened by hyperbolic language.

deliberation: I noted three relational images: God as Father, God as potter vs the people as clay, and the people as the work of His hand. The father image and the potter-clay/work-of-hand image are two distinct metaphors; the last clause expands the potter imagery.

instances.english_text: O YHWH, You are our Father
target: God’s covenantal relation to His people
vehicle: A human father in relation to his children
ground: Both involve origin, care, discipline, and claim upon the children’s loyalty
posture: The speaker appeals to God’s paternal commitment as a basis for mercy
instances.explanation: Calling God ‘our Father’ is a relational metaphor: His covenant role is depicted in terms of a human father’s generating, caring, and disciplining functions toward his children.

instances.hebrew_text: אֲנַחְנוּ הַחֹמֶר וְאַתָּה יֹצְרֵנוּ וּמַעֲשֵׂה יָדְךָ כֻּלָּנוּ
instances.english_text: We are the clay, and You are our Potter; we are all the work of Your hands
target: The people’s dependence and malleability before God
vehicle: Clay shaped by a potter’s hands into a vessel
ground: Both clay and people are shaped, purposed, and disposed of by a higher will
posture: The speaker underscores God’s right and capacity to refashion or spare them
instances.explanation: The community is likened to clay in a potter’s hands—passive, moldable, and wholly shaped by the artisan—while God is portrayed as the potter whose ‘hands’ produce them. This extended metaphor stresses God’s creative authority and their dependence.

deliberation: I explored whether ‘be not angry’ and ‘do not remember iniquity forever’ are literal descriptions of God’s states or conventional figures. The key figurative expression is ‘remember iniquity forever,’ which uses ‘remember’ metonymically for ongoing punitive regard, with ‘forever’ as rhetorical hyperbole.

instances.english_text: Do not remember iniquity forever
target: God’s continued holding of their sins against them in judgment
vehicle: Remembering something in one’s mind indefinitely
ground: To keep something ‘in mind’ corresponds to continuing to treat it as operative and effective
Mental retention as basis for ongoing action
posture: The speaker pleads for God to cease regarding their sins as a standing charge
instances.explanation: ‘Remember iniquity’ is not about mere cognition but uses remembrance metonymically for maintaining sin on the docket of judgment, with ‘forever’ heightening the plea that God not perpetually treat them as guilty.

deliberation: I considered whether the devastation language is purely literal or also figurative. Describing the ‘holy cities’ and ‘Zion’ as a ‘desert’ and ‘desolation’ employs desolate landscape imagery as a metaphor/hyperbole for thorough ruin, whether or not sand is literally present.

instances.hebrew_text: עָרֵי קׇדְשְׁךָ הָיוּ מִדְבָּר צִיּוֹן מִדְבָּר הָיָתָה יְרוּשָׁלַ͏ִם שְׁמָמָה
instances.english_text: Your holy cities have become a desert; Zion has become a desert, Jerusalem a desolation
target: The condition of Judah’s key cities after judgment
ground: Both ruined cities and deserts lack inhabitants, productivity, and normal social life
Absence of life, order, and security
posture: The speaker laments the cities’ condition by using the starkest landscape imagery
instances.explanation: Calling the ‘holy cities,’ especially Zion/Jerusalem, a ‘desert’ and ‘desolation’ uses barren-wasteland imagery as metaphor and hyperbole for their utter ruin and depopulation.

deliberation: I examined whether ‘house,’ ‘holy,’ ‘our glory,’ and ‘all our pleasant things’ function figuratively. In Hebrew the ‘house of our holiness and our splendor’ straightforwardly denotes the temple; its having been burned with fire and the beloved things ruined are literal historical descriptions. I did not find a clearly distinct figurative expression beyond inherent reverential language.

I evaluated the verbs describing God’s apparent inaction: ‘restrain Yourself’ and ‘be silent.’ Both are anthropomorphic/metaphorical for God’s not intervening to save, using bodily self-control and silence as vehicles. I treat them as two related but distinct images.

instances.english_text: At such things will You restrain Yourself, O YHWH?
target: God’s choice not to act decisively in response to the disaster
vehicle: A person holding themselves back, exercising self-control
ground: Refraining from action despite provocation parallels choosing not to intervene despite severe suffering
posture: The speaker challenges God’s apparent inaction by picturing Him as one who could but does not ‘step in’
instances.explanation: God is likened to a person who restrains himself from intervening, an anthropomorphic metaphor for His apparent refusal to act despite circumstances that seem to demand it.

instances.english_text: Will You be silent and let us suffer so heavily?
target: God’s apparent non-response to the people’s plight
vehicle: Remaining silent instead of speaking or acting
ground: Silence functions as a sign of indifference or non-intervention
No speech corresponds to no saving action
posture: The speaker equates God’s ‘silence’ with His allowing severe affliction to continue
Urgent appeal for a break in the silence
instances.explanation: Describing God as ‘silent’ uses human silence metonymically and metaphorically for His failure to act or speak in deliverance; the question protests that continued ‘silence’ amid heavy affliction is intolerable.
